a1: A MAC (Media Access Control) address is a unique 48-bit identifier assigned to network interfaces, typically displayed as 6 hex pairs.
a2: The least significant bit of the first byte. When 0 (unicast), the address represents a single device. When 1 (multicast), it represents a group.
a3: The second least significant bit of the first byte. When set, it indicates the MAC was assigned locally rather than by the manufacturer.
q4: Can I use generated MACs for testing?
a4: Yes, these are ideal for testing, development, and virtual machine configuration. Use locally administered unicast MACs to avoid conflicts.
